Journeys to the human past: documenting megalithic monuments on Wikipedia \\ Ronny Ueckermann (User:Einsamer Schütze)


What are megalith

Megaliths are monuments made of large erratic stones. There are tombs (Dolmens, passage graves), temples and single stones (Menhirs). Megalithic monuments were built all over the world by different peoples at different times. In northern and western Europe these momuments were erected during the neolithic and early bronze age ( $6^{\text {th }}-3^{\text {rd }}$ millennium BCE )

How many are there?

In northern Europe there were once up to 30.000 monuments but just a fraction was documented and less than 4000 still exist today:
- Germany: $\sim 5800$ documented ( $\sim 1150$ preserved)
- Denmark: ~6000 documented (2067 preserved)
- Sweden: 650 documented (489 preserved)
- Norway: 5 documented (2 preserved)
- Netherlands: 81 documented ( 55 preserved)
- Poland: 200 documented (? preserved)
- Sum: $\sim 12700$ documented ( $-3800+$ preserved)

There is probably the same amount in western Europe

How were they documented?

Megalithic monuments in northern Europe were documented by scolars since the early days of archaeology in the late $18^{\text {th }}$ and early $19^{\text {th }}$ century. Since the 1820 ies there were many attempts to document all monuments in certain smaller regions and since the early $20^{\text {th }}$ century there were attempts to document all monuments in whole countries. Until today only the scandinavian countries have created public databases for all monuments. For the other countries there are only printed documentations that are often multiple decades old. Besides that there are many private websites, that are mostly just photo collections of existing and easily accessible sites.

What can Wikioedians do?

Wikipedia could be an ideal place to connect scientific accuracy and private enthusiasm. With an international community it is possible to collect all megalithic sites in Europe, to describe them, to provide all relevant bibliographical references and to take photos of all the sites.

What has beer achieved sc ar?
In late 2009 we began at the German Wikipedia to compile lists for all megalithic sites in Germany and later for the neighbouring countries. The Lists for Germany, Sweden, Norway and the Netherlands are completed, the Lists for Denmark and Poland are not finished yet. Thanks to financial support by Wikimedia Deutschland since 2013 six excursions have taken place to systematically photograph sites in Germany. 115 megalithic tombs and several other sites have been visited so far.
For more information see
https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProjekt_Megalithik
e future goal
Complete Lists and articles for all sites in northern europe Translate them to other languages
Finish the photographic documentation
Expand our work to western Europe and beyond
